quiz.text: Quantity I: A vessel contains liquids A and B in a ratio of 5:3. If 16 liters of the mixture are removed and the same quantity of liquid B is added, the ratio becomes 3:5. What quantity does the vessel hold initially? Quantity II: A mixture contains milk and water in the ratio of 4:3 respectively. If 6 liters of water is added to this mixture, the respective ratio of milk and water becomes 8:7. What is the quantity of milk in the original mixture?
options: Quantity I> Quantity II
Quantity I< Quantity II
Quantity I ≤ Quantity II
Quantity I ≥ Quantity II
Quantity I= Quantity II

quiz.text: Quantity I: A train travelling 25 km an hour leaves Delhi at 9 a.m and another train travelling 35 km an hour starts at 2 p.m,in the same direction, how many kms from Delhi will they meet together? Quantity II: Two trains start at the same time from two stations and proceed towards each other at the rates of 20km/hr and 25 km/hr respectively. When they meet, it is found that one train has travelled 80 km more than the other. Find the distance between the two stations.
options: Quantity I> Quantity II
Quantity I< Quantity II
Quantity I≤ Quantity II
Quantity I ≥ Quantity II
Quantity I= Quantity II

quiz.text: Quantity I: Two pipes can separately fill the tank in 20 hours and 30 hours respectively. Both the pipes are open to fill the tank, but when the tank is 1/3 full a leak develops in the tank through which 1/3 of the water supplied by both the pipes per hour leak out, what is the total time taken to fill the tank? Quantity II: A tank has two pipes. The first pipe can fill it in 45 minutes and the second can empty it in 1 hour. In what time will the empty tank be filled if the pipes are opened one at a time in alternate minutes?
options: Quantity I> Quantity II
Quantity I< Quantity II
Quantity I ≤ Quantity II
Quantity I ≥ Quantity II
Quantity I= Quantity II

quiz.text: Quantity I: A boatman can row a certain distance downstream in 2 hours and upstream the same distance in 3 hour, if the stream flows at the rate of 4km/hr, what is the speed of the boat in still water? Quantity II: A boat goes 6 km upstream and back again to the starting point in 2 hours. If the velocity of the stream is 4 km/hr, what is the speed of the boat in still water?
options: Quantity I> Quantity II
Quantity I< Quantity II
Quantity I ≤ Quantity II
Quantity I ≥ Quantity II
Quantity I= Quantity II

quiz.text: Ram and Prakash play a game of numbers in which each player in his turn has to choose a positive integer that is less than the previous number and at least equal to half of the previous number. The player who chooses 1 in his turn (with no other integer left) loses and the game ends there. Ram starts the game by choosing 2021 and after that, both the players start playing the game with their best strategy. Which integer should Prakash choose immediately after Ram has chosen 2021 to ensure his own victory
options: 1535
11
1025
2049
None of these

quiz.text: When the digits of a three-digit number N are written in reverse order, we get a three-digit number M. Which of the following statements is/are correct about the three-digit number S which results from the addition of numbers M and N? a) At most, S can only have 2 of the 3 digits even b) Number S can’t be a prime number c) Each of the three digits in number S is greater than 2.
options: A & B
B & C
A & C
C & A
None of these

quiz.text: What is the volume of milk in container A? Statement I: Ratio of milk in A to B is 6:7. Statement II: 34 liters of mixture is poured from A to C such that milk in C becomes 24 liters less than the milk originally present in B. Statement III: Ratio of water to milk in A and C respectively is 8:9 and 8:7 respectively
options: Only I is sufficient
Any two of the three statements
I and either of II and III.
All I, II and III are required.
Can’t be determined

quiz.text: What is the perimeter of the rectangle? Statement I: Area of circle is 6 times of the area of the rectangle. Statement II: Sum of perimeter of the rectangle and the square is 144 cm. Length of the rectangle is 1cm more than the length of the square. Statement III: If the radius of the circle is reduced to its half, its area will be 53.5 cm2 less than the square’s area.
options: Only I is sufficient
Any two of the three statements
I and either of II and III are sufficient
All I, II and III are required.
Can’t be determined

options: Only I is sufficient
Any two of the three statements
I and either of II and III are sufficient.
All I, II and III are required.
